captions.text:
Behind the back grabs, in front of the body
grabs, now we're going to move into the final

section of the yellow belt test, which is
strikes. The first strike is called Munetsuki.

Mune, again is mid-level, Tsuki being strike.
So, Munetsuki Kotegaeishi is the technique.

As he goes into strike, he has to make sure
that he punches me in the stomach. One of

my worst pet peeves is when people punch out
here. I don't care if he punches out here.

I don't care if he punches out here, if he
does that all day long, all he's doing is

fanning me. It's making me cool off. So he
has to punch like he's going to make me see

my lunch. As he does that, I do my Tenkan
motion that we talked about in the very beginning,

this turning motion. So as he strikes, I Tenkan,
control this wrist, and bring him back around.

Principle of Dynamic Reversal. It's a bad
spot to turn someone right around into this,

because you're giving him momentum to strike
you with. If you watch his other hand, boom,

he could really clean your clock from here.
So you have to maintain control of this wrist

from the very beginning. One, two. From here,
Kotegaeishi, like I talked before, is not

a wrist lock out to the side, like this. A
lot of styles like Aikido you'll see a big

huge wrist lock, which gives it a really pretty
fall, it looks very impressive on camera.

But in reality, it gives him a lot of opportunity
to punch, or to just knock my hands off, and

put me in Kotegaeishi myself. So instead we
keep our Kotegaeishis very small, and you'll

see from the next one I control the entire
body with this.
You'll also see, I moved right into the pin

that I discussed before. Extending the shoulder
into the ground, maintaining control, I've

got my entire workspace laid out before me.
I used to do this technique to pin to the

outside, but if he starts to move away, it's
too easy for me to lose that. So from here,

I've got him pinned here, and if he starts
to get away, I can transition into a strike,

to a head grab, to a knee drop, anything that
I need is right here at my feet. Control the
arm, step away.

comments.text:
Twice I've had people strain my elbow tendons applying kotegaeshi. I had 
tennis elbow for a while because of that, but eventually cured it with 
Dolobid. Steven Seagal seems to use kotagaeshi a lot in his films and its 
usually against an opponent with a knife. We often practiced it using 
wooden knives.

I'll say this. If you dont know how to breakfall you can get seriously beat 
up with this technique.

On the street, it can best be used against someone that is grabbing your 
wrists, against someone that tries to grab you from behind, against someone 
who is swinging a baseball bat at your head in a diagonal plane from above, 
or against someone that is trying to throw a right or left hook at your 
head. If things go right they will not be getting up to go at you again.

To apply most Aikido in a street or police or a self defense context, 
things should be already on a reflex level. A reflex response. They're 
combative and they come past ma-ai, you respond. In any of those contexts 
ma-ai is the key concept and it should be a very real thing to you to the 
point that you just feel it the second they reach the ma-ai distance. Has 
to be like that and you should practice recognizing that in everyday life 
just as you should practice your breathing in motion and maintaining your 
center ( hara ). It must be a part of your life.﻿
comments.author: Kay Barriere

comments.text:
I could not agree less with your opinions....my grand master once said " 
read one book hundreds times rather than read hundred books but only 
once".......meaning ; we repeat certain technique over and over again to 
understand it batter and to make it like second nature to 
ourselves....easiest examples like walking or eating.....when you walk you 
don't have to consciously tell you brain to move right leg or left....you 
just move without thinking......similarly...what we want to achieve are 
ability of reflect without the stages of brain assessment process then 
react...  Food for thought; For a Samurai how many "Kamae" he must know and 
master......

comments.text:
Aikido, like Taiji, can be a martial art, a spiritual path, or both 
depending on the practitioner.

You calling it a watered-down art seems to assert you've already finished 
judging it. Aikido is a more intricate art than, say, Muay Thai (an art I 
also have a great deal of respect for), and takes much longer to learn. I 
believe it is viable, and I've also studied Muay Thai, Xingyi, and Kenpo. 
However, having never used Aikido in a street fight, I won't claim 
experience.

Hope that helps.
comments.author: Philo Sophia

comments.text:
a lot of you guys just don't realize, aikido is a purely defensive style. 
that means all that force you're coming in with, if the defending person 
moves out of the line you're giving him, he can literally do as he pleases 
with you.

this is completely the ideal situation with the ideal aikido practitioner. 

step out of your muay that jujitsu bubble and you'll start to see﻿

comments.text:
It's funny to hear "that would not work in real life". If the techniques of 
Aikido wouldn't work in real life, then Aikido wouldn't be around anymore. 
It would have completely faded away into history. I don't think any style 
or Martial Art is the best. The one's that are still around do have useful 
techniques. I'm not a fan of TaeKwonDo, but at least I know that there are 
some useful techniques within it. To completely disregard something, 
anything, without trying it, is an act of foolishness.

I practice alone. I live in a town so for my training I run to a place in a 
Maine call Auburn and run up Mt. Appatite then practice my Martial Arts at 
the top of this Mountain. I look up videos on all Martial Arts and practice 
what I learn but also go along with what Grandmaster IP Man taught Bruce 
Lee: It is not technique or style one must master, it is being prepared and 
having the feeling to know where and when you opponent will strike.
comments.author: Reach Mann

comments.text:
Thank you. I have no training partner which I am trying to find one, but I

comments.author: Reach Mann

comments.text:
Curious... if there are only Karate Dojos in your area, how are you 
training the other arts?
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
Stretch after warming up every day and stretch during your cool down after 
training. Look up some good leg stretches online for help. During drills 
and warm up, have a partner (or use an obstacle of some sort) with an arm 
held so the upper arm is level with the shoulder and the lower arm bends to 
point straight down. Practice kicks straight up into this space. That will 
help with flexibility and accuracy. When you are comfortable with the kicks 
there, close the gap slightly.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
I live in Maine so there are no Dojos other than for Karate and there is no 
Sparring.
comments.author: Reach Mann

comments.text:
Those are all Martial Arts I am trying to Master. I know much of Bruce Lee 
and I know this quote. I mean what is the best way to stretch your legs to 
kick better because I have seen a large man whose able to kick straight up 
while standing up straight.
comments.author: Reach Mann

comments.text:
Train an art that focuses on kicks. Taekwondo comes to mind as well as 
Kickboxing or Muay Thai. Capoeria or Jeet Kun Do might also help. Take 
Bruce Lee's quote: "I fear not the man who has practiced 10,000 kicks once, 
but I fear the man who has practiced one kick 10,000 times." Repetition is 
everything. When you are sparring, try getting quick kicks in when you can 
regardless of contact. In Aikido, if both partners are of proper rank, we 
train to tag openings, kicks included.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text: Okay, Thank you. What is the best way to improve your kicks?
comments.author: Reach Mann

someone in.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
Traditional Judo (as opposed to sport judo) does train throws from strikes, 
but Judo in a whole is a throw-based art. Aikido doesn't train strikes like 
Karate or Boxing, but it does work with them more than Judo (but unless 
there are strikers or strikes taught, they aren't terribly practical 
attacks). Both arts focus on throws and takedowns. Judo tends to lean 
towards the throw more (a good throw can disable someone) while Aikido 
tends to lean towards control after the takedown via pins.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
Both arts take years to be applicable in a self-defense situation. If you 
want fast results, go with Krav Maga of a similar art. Aikido is, I 
believe, one of the best self-defense arts out there not because of the 
techniques, but because you train to read intentions. Once you can do that, 
you can spot a bad situation from a mile away and avoid it all together. 
And if it ends up being unavoidable, you've got technique to cover you.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
So, you have your left foot forward and he punches with his left, correct? 
You wouldn't need to do this or any technique really. In order to hit you, 
he'd need to cross your body essentially. While moving in, he's very open 
to a front kick or snap kick. That's why we train to attack the side that 
they have forward: it's harder for them to kick.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
But in most cases a 9mm round isn't enough to kill. The shot needs to be 
very accurate and if the person is hell-bent on attacking you, a small 
round like that won't slow them down. Read up on the reports of soldiers 
involved in the Somolia incident with Black Hawk Down. One of their major 
complaints was that the ammo they used was too small and didn't have any 
stopping power. They used AR rounds larger than 9mm and couldn't drop 
people right away.
comments.author: Nathan Stillings

comments.text:
